Joe - Wrong. Overeating (too many calories) makes a person fat, because excess (unburned) calories are stored as fat in the human body.

Dietary fats have 50% more calories per gram than either carbs or sugars, so overeating fats will put a person over their calorie needs faster than overeating carbs or sugars. I find it stunning anyone needs to be told this simple relationship between food types, food intake, and weight gain.

As with other major sports, playing the game at the highest level has become more physically demanding than it was in those golden years. Nothing against those pitchers, but they faced lineups that included players that were slower, fatter, weaker and quite likely, hungover.

Pitching more than 250 innings in a season? Consider these pitchers: Warren Spahn: from 1947 through 1963, there was only one year in which he did not pitch more than 250 innings; he only pitched 245.2 that year. In 1963, he was 42, and went only 23–7. He had 13 20  game seasons during that period, and pitched more than 300 innings twice. Early Wynn pitched more than 250 for eight consecutive years, 1951-59 (ages 31-39), winning 20 or more five of those years. Whitey Ford first pitched more than 250 in 1961, when he was 32. He also did it the next two seasons, winning 25, 17, and 24 during those years. Sandy Koufax, meanwhile, also pitched more than 250 in '61, when he was 25. He pitched more than 300 in 1965 and 66, winning 26 and 27 games in those years. There are more of course. (And, from the same era, consider the extraordinary relief careers of Hoyt Wilhelm and Roy Face.)Those were golden years for baseball and baseball fans. I'm not sure what Casey Stengel would have thought of pitch counts, but I think the answer is – – not much. As an aging Baby Boomer, I have spent entirely too much time wondering aloud why the pitchers of my youth were able to do what no pitcher would be asked to consider today.

I'm sorry, but the fact that you think only an "unending screaming rage" should prompt an exit (and even in that case, you say only "perhaps" a departure from the table would be in order) suggests that your desire to create memories for your family trumps other people's desire to enjoy making memories of their own. I am a parent of two young children, and my husband and I try to be very mindful about when and where we take our children out to eat. If we want to chance a higher-end restaurant, we go at brunch, not dinner. My children are well-behaved at table, but we must also acknowledge that we ask a great deal of little bodies that they sit still and listen to grown-ups drone on and on for hours on end. We've had far more memorable meals at our own dining room tables than at any of the restaurants we've visited since our children were born.

In 1968 Humphrey was glued to Johnson, and Johnson was glued to the Vietnam war. He had also gotten the civil rights act passed, and while most of us loved it, Johnson said on signing it that he had just lost the south to the GOP. Nixon didn't really believe in very much other than himself, and he claimed to have a secret plan to end the war. He also had his southern strategy. In 1968, there were riots in Chicago, McCarthy ran for president (Eugene, not Joseph), and the second Kennedy brother was shot. Martin Luther King turned against the war (if he had ever been for it), and then he too was killed. I think after awhile people just wanted things to be normal, and Nixon pretended to do that. In 1972 we had McGovern, who I supported, and Nixon. Don't forget Wallace. Nixon again got away with seeming to be moderate.
We have had many progressive candidates over the years, and why none of them has succeeded I can't say. The Republicans have been the Republicans for a very long time and I won't go into how they came to be this way. I think the failure of progressivism lies more in the Democratic Party. As I have said before I am just waiting to see which candidate the Democrats nominate, and I will support them. Then it will be up to the voters. Democracy means letting the people have what they want, and hard!

I'm glad Bernie's getting out his message of economic equality. It's critical the Democratic Party retain the White House and take back the House and Senate if any of our economic, infrastructure and climate problems are going to be seriously addressed in the NEXT five years (as they've been ignored for the last seven by Congress.)

But the Sanders/Clinton contest is doing a lot of damage to party unity, particularly by the quality of media coverage it's being given. For example - it's interesting a caucus "win" and a primary "win" are treated as identical in this piece. In the former, a few thousand votes - at most - are cast; in the latter, hundreds of thousands of votes are cast. Hillary has won nearly every primary state (which is why she leads by nearly 3 million votes cast).

Bernie's "wins" are almost all lower-voting caucus states. That's been his strategy, regardless of how Tad Devine or anyone else on the campaign is recasting "regret" now. And if Nevada is any indication, he has a lot of former Rand/Ron Paul supporters in his campaign now. The attacks are more personal; truth-stretching has crossed the line into misrepresentation ("Misinformation works" - Rand Paul), and the evasions - particularly his puzzling refusal to release his tax returns - are tarnishing Bernie's persona of "trustworthiness" while his caucus wins impart seeming "momentum."

I'm disappointed his "revolution" is seemingly dependent on the most common tricks in the Republican playbook.
